name: Custom - common-grant.pdf
description: Custom uploaded template with AI-generated sample answers

sections.title: Cover Sheet
sections.description: Basic information about the applicant organization and the project.

questions.text: Are you currently receiving United Way Program Funding? Identify programs and amount:
questions.sample_answer: Yes. We currently receive $25,000 annually for our youth mentoring program and $10,000 for our adult literacy program.

questions.text: Contact Person/Title (if different from Executive Director)
Mailing Address, if different from above

questions.sample_answer: To provide underprivileged youth with access to computers and technology training.

questions.text: Beginning and Ending Dates of the Project/Campaign

sections.title: Narrative
sections.description: Detailed description of the organization and the proposed project.

questions.sample_answer: Community Support Network Inc. was founded in 1998 with a mission to empower underserved communities.  We began by offering adult literacy classes and have since expanded to include youth programs, job training initiatives, and community outreach events. Our consistent growth and impact on the Anytown community have solidified our reputation as a reliable and effective service provider.

questions.text: State your mission and goals, future challenges, and long-range plans.
questions.sample_answer: Our mission is to provide resources and opportunities that promote self-sufficiency and community growth. Our goal is to expand our reach to serve a wider population while maintaining the high quality of our existing programs. Future challenges include securing sustainable funding and adapting to evolving community needs. Our long-range plan involves establishing a community center offering a comprehensive range of services under one roof.

Currently, we operate three core programs: adult literacy, youth mentoring, and job skills training. Each program provides essential services to residents of Anytown, focusing on improving employment prospects, education levels, and overall quality of life.  We also regularly host community events focused on health, wellness and financial literacy.

Over the past five years, we've helped over 100 adults improve their literacy skills, mentored more than 50 at-risk youth, and placed 75 individuals in sustainable employment.  We consistently receive positive feedback from participants and the broader community, highlighting the effectiveness and impact of our initiatives.

questions.text: Differentiate yourself from similar or competing organizations.
questions.sample_answer: While other organizations in Anytown provide similar services, Community Support Network Inc. distinguishes itself through our holistic approach, integrating multiple programs to address interconnected needs within the community.  Our collaborative partnerships with local businesses and schools also ensure we're addressing the most urgent and relevant issues facing our residents.

questions.text: Describe the proposed program or project.
questions.sample_answer: The "Empowering Youth Through Technology" project aims to bridge the digital divide among underprivileged youth in Anytown by providing access to computers, internet connectivity, and technology training.  This will equip them with essential skills for future education and employment opportunities, empowering them to thrive in an increasingly digital world.

questions.text: Identify the needs/problems to be addressed, target population and number of people to be served by the project.
questions.sample_answer: The project addresses the lack of access to technology and digital literacy among low-income youth in Anytown.  The target population is 50 youth aged 13-18 from low-income families. We will serve 50 youth through this project over the course of one year. This will give them the tools they need to succeed in school and beyond.

questions.text: Describe the project goals and objectives, and your plan to meet them.
questions.sample_answer: The project's primary goal is to improve digital literacy among 50 underprivileged youth.  Objectives include providing computer access for 2 hours per week for 50 participants; delivering 10 weeks of technology training; and achieving a 90% completion rate in the technology training program. We will achieve this by partnering with local schools and community centers to provide access to computers and by hiring qualified technology instructors.

questions.text: Define the project as a new or continuing program.
Identify other organizations, partners or funders participating in the project and their roles.
questions.sample_answer: We are partnering with Anytown High School, which will provide classroom space for our technology training program. They will also help us identify eligible youth participants.  The local library will provide additional computer access during off-school hours.

Phase 1 (January-March): Secure funding, recruit instructors, and acquire equipment. Phase 2 (April-June):  Set up computer lab, recruit students, and begin technology training program. Phase 3 (July-December): Continue the technology training program, evaluate student progress, and prepare final reports.

We plan to explore additional grant opportunities from other foundations and corporate sponsors to ensure the long-term sustainability of this program.  We will also seek in-kind donations of equipment from technology companies and explore partnerships with local businesses to offer internship opportunities for our students.

questions.text: If a similar program or service has been conducted by your organization or another, please discuss its impact. Does it represent an expansion or duplication of services in your area? If it doesn’t, define its potential to serve as a model program locally or nationally.
questions.sample_answer: This program is new to our organization and, to our knowledge, represents a gap in service in Anytown.  Its success could serve as a model for other communities facing similar challenges by demonstrating the effectiveness of a holistic approach to addressing digital literacy and youth empowerment. The program’s structure is scalable and adaptable for diverse contexts.

questions.text: Describe your plan to document progress and results.
questions.sample_answer: We will conduct regular progress monitoring to track attendance rates, student engagement, and learning outcomes.  We will also conduct pre- and post-tests to measure improvement in digital literacy skills and administer a final evaluation survey to assess program impact.  We'll provide interim and final expenditure reports as required and maintain open communication with the grantor throughout the project.

sections.title: Attachments
sections.description: Required documents to support the application.

questions.text: Copy of the current IRS determination letter indicating 501(c)(3) tax-exempt status.

Organizational structure, including: List of officers and directors, including occupations, places of employment, and relevant affiliations; Description of board responsibilities, including committee assignments; Resumes and/or job descriptions of key personnel involved in the project.

Finances, including: Grant budget; List of other funders, potential funders and amounts committed or requested, including public contracts, individual contributions and other sources of income supporting the project; Current board-approved annual operating budget, including expenses and income; Most recent audited annual financial statement; Letters of support (optional) that substantiate need for the project and collaboration with other organizations; Annual report, if available.

sections.title: Budget
sections.description: Detailed breakdown of project expenses and income.

questions.text: Please specify the budget period (e.g. January 1, 1996 to December 30, 1996).
Salaries and wages by individual position, specifying full- or part-time positions
Consultant and professional fees (e.g. accounting, legal, etc.)

questions.sample_answer: Anytown High School is providing classroom space and internet access valued at $5,000.  The local library is providing additional computer access valued at $2,000.

questions.text: United Way, Combined Federal Campaign or other federated campaigns
